docs.lead_paragraph: AT 33, Bill O'Donnell Jr. had succeeded. He was vice president of Bally Manufacturing, had an annual salary of $150,000, owned two Mercedes Benz's and an expensive house in Winnetka, Ill. He also cheated on his wife, missed meetings he had called and used 4 grams of cocaine a day. ''I was pursuing the American Dream, and I thought cocaine would get me there faster,'' he said. ''I was running through life so fast I didn't see that my role as a husband and father to my three sons was disintegrating, that my business abilities were crumbling.''

docs.lead_paragraph: In New Mexico last month, the authorities seized 1,184 pounds of cocaine hidden in a pickup truck. Days earlier, the police seized 700 pounds of cocaine being smuggled into Phoenix, and 1,253 pounds in West Palm Beach, Fla. In the last few weeks, law-enforcement authorities working in at least 15 states have seized more than 6,000 pounds of cocaine, nearly a month's supply for the United States. And, Bolivian authorities working with the United States Army say they have ended cocaine production in that country, at least temporarily, through raids over the last six weeks. It is estimated that these raids have cut off 20 percent to 40 percent of the United States' cocaine supply. But even with all this cocaine being kept off the American market, enforcement officials say that the price of the drug has not risen and that cocaine remains widely available on the streets.

headline.main: EXPERTS SEE U.S. COCAINE PROBLEM AS CONTINUING DESPITE ANTIDRUG RAIDS

byline.original: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The new tax bill is a major step forward for low-income families, easing a tax burden that has grown increasingly heavy on them over the past decade, according to a variety of experts. While other aspects of the tax revision plan have sparked opposition in the week since the bill's approval by a House-Senate conference committee, both liberal and conservative groups have hailed the bill's treatment of low-income working people. Under the bill, an estimated 6 million low-income households would be dropped from the tax rolls entirely. By 1988, households earning less than $10,000 would see their taxes reduced, on average, by 65.7 percent, according to the Joint Committee on Taxation. Taxes would drop by 22.3 percent among households earning between $10,000 and $20,000 a year.

headline.main: MAJOR HELP FOUND IN TAX BILL FOR LOW-INCOME HOUSEHOLDS
